Award.AwardTitle: Optimal siRNA Design based on Whole Genome Thermodynamic Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Iowa State University is awarded a grant to develop small interference RNA (siRNA) design software. RNA interference (RNAi) is a natural phenomenon in cells where siRNAs guide the recognition, inhibition and potential degradation of target messenger RNAs (mRNA), resulting in the lost of their gene functions. RNAi is an important molecular biology technology that can be used to perform functional genomic studies. It is also suggested that siRNAs can be used as drugs to stop oncogenes in cancer cells or to fight off viruses. The RNAi technology depends on the quality of the artificially designed siRNAs - the most critical task is to discover siRNAs that are efficient in knocking down their target genes but produce no disturbance to the other tens of thousands of genes coexisting in cells. Reducing or eliminating side-effects can dramatically enhance the precision of RNAi technology. In fact, eliminating side-effects will be the basic requirement of any RNAi uses in medicine.

The two main goals of this project are 1) to create novel siRNA design software that can select high quality, gene-specific siRNAs based on the comprehensive thermodynamic analysis of an entire genome and 2) to validate the quality of the designed siRNAs with RNAi experiments. The intellectual merit of this project is the use of thermodynamic calculation in a whole-genome scale to perform optimal siRNA selection. The RNAi experiments will not only test the siRNAs but also guide the refinements to the project software algorithms and parameters. The broader impact that is expected from this project will be the most precise siRNA design software tool for biologists to use in their research. In addition, this project will provide an ideal interdisciplinary training environment for both computer science and biology graduate students to work together and advance in computational biology research. The software developed under this project will be made available from the Complex Computation Lab website at Iowa State University .

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

POR.DRECONTENT:
RNA interference is a natural phenomenon in cells where small interference RNAs (siRNAs) guide the recognition, inhibition and degradation of target genes, resulting in the loss of their functions. RNA interference is an important molecular biology technology that has many applications. It has also been suggested that siRNAs can function as drugs to stop oncogenes in cancer cells or fight off invading viruses, providing a new therapeutic alternative to protein-targeting drugs and gene therapies.

For the technology to be successful, a critical task is to design siRNAs that are highly efficient in knocking down target genes, but produce no disturbance to the other tens of thousands of non-target genes coexisting in cells. Reducing or eliminating siRNA side-effects can enhance the precision of siRNA experiments and reduce the cost associated with this new technology. Eliminating siRNA side-effects is also the basic requirement for their application in medicine.

The two goals of this project are 1) to develop novel siRNA design software that can select high-quality, gene-specific siRNAs based on the thermodynamic analysis of an entire genome, and 2) to validate the quality of the siRNAs designed by this software with experiments on various species. The organization of project goals is depicted in Figure 1.

At the center of the project is the development of the siRNA design software Picky that can perform whole-genome thermodynamic analysis of target species. Because siRNAs have to specifically hybridize, or bind, to their target genes to inhibit them, thermodynamic analysis provides more precise predictions of their targets and potential non-targets, allowing us to select siRNAs that work best against their intended targets while exerting no side-effects on other genes. This goal of the project was reached with the release of Picky version 2.20, which is publicly available and has many applications in addition to siRNA designs.

Testing of Picky designed siRNAs on mammalian cells provides conclusive evidence that they are indeed gene-specific. Since Picky also predicts non-targets for each siRNA, it allows researchers to control side-effects by monitoring these non-target genes. An example of our results is shown in Figure 2. While performing the tests, we also analyzed hundreds of naturally occurring microRNAs which function similarly to siRNAs, and linked them to their hybridization structures with target genes. This work sheds lights on microRNA target predictions.

We have developed a new siRNA delivery construct based on short hairpin RNAs (shRNAs) to test Picky designed siRNAs on the animal model C. elegans. Traditionally, long double-stranded RNAs (dsRNAs) have been used in this species, but can produce many random siRNAs that cause side-effects. We have used both constructs to target the same genes in deletion mutants of C. elegans that lack the targeted genes. The rationale is that in deletion mutants, any gene expression changes caused by siRNAs are likely side-effects. We have obtained evidence that our siRNAs have limited side-effects compared to dsRNAs. An example is shown in Figure 3. However, we were disappointed that our siRNAs delivered by shRNA constructs induced much weaker gene inhibition than dsRNAs. In other words, we ran into a dilemma that our siRNAs are more gene-specific but weaker, and the traditional dsRNAs are stronger but not always gene-specific.

We have tried various transient plant transfection methods to test Picky designed siRNAs in the plant model Arabidopsis, but we found none that work well. Ironically, our attempt to speed up the project by using transient plant transfection methods actually delayed our work. We later decided to go back to using the permanent Arabidopsis transfection method mediated by Agrobacterium tumefaciens to create Arabidopsis mutants that em...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: RNA interference is a natural phenomenon in cells where small interference RNAs (siRNAs) guide the recognition, inhibition and degradation of target genes, resulting in the loss of their functions. RNA interference is an important molecular biology technology that has many applications. It has also been suggested that siRNAs can function as drugs to stop oncogenes in cancer cells or fight off invading viruses, providing a new therapeutic alternative to protein-targeting drugs and gene therapies. For the technology to be successful, a critical task is to design siRNAs that are highly efficient in knocking down target genes, but produce no disturbance to the other tens of thousands of non-target genes coexisting in cells. Reducing or eliminating siRNA side-effects can enhance the precision of siRNA experiments and reduce the cost associated with this new technology. Eliminating siRNA side-effects is also the basic requirement for their application in medicine. The two goals of this project are 1) to develop novel siRNA design software that can select high-quality, gene-specific siRNAs based on the thermodynamic analysis of an entire genome, and 2) to validate the quality of the siRNAs designed by this software with experiments on various species. The organization of project goals is depicted in Figure 1. At the center of the project is the development of the siRNA design software Picky that can perform whole-genome thermodynamic analysis of target species. Because siRNAs have to specifically hybridize, or bind, to their target genes to inhibit them, thermodynamic analysis provides more precise predictions of their targets and potential non-targets, allowing us to select siRNAs that work best against their intended targets while exerting no side-effects on other genes. This goal of the project was reached with the release of Picky version 2.20, which is publicly available and has many applications in addition to siRNA designs. Testing of Picky designed siRNAs on mammalian cells provides conclusive evidence that they are indeed gene-specific. Since Picky also predicts non-targets for each siRNA, it allows researchers to control side-effects by monitoring these non-target genes. An example of our results is shown in Figure 2. While performing the tests, we also analyzed hundreds of naturally occurring microRNAs which function similarly to siRNAs, and linked them to their hybridization structures with target genes. This work sheds lights on microRNA target predictions. We have developed a new siRNA delivery construct based on short hairpin RNAs (shRNAs) to test Picky designed siRNAs on the animal model C. elegans. Traditionally, long double-stranded RNAs (dsRNAs) have been used in this species, but can produce many random siRNAs that cause side-effects. We have used both constructs to target the same genes in deletion mutants of C. elegans that lack the targeted genes. The rationale is that in deletion mutants, any gene expression changes caused by siRNAs are likely side-effects. We have obtained evidence that our siRNAs have limited side-effects compared to dsRNAs. An example is shown in Figure 3. However, we were disappointed that our siRNAs delivered by shRNA constructs induced much weaker gene inhibition than dsRNAs. In other words, we ran into a dilemma that our siRNAs are more gene-specific but weaker, and the traditional dsRNAs are stronger but not always gene-specific. We have tried various transient plant transfection methods to test Picky designed siRNAs in the plant model Arabidopsis, but we found none that work well. Ironically, our attempt to speed up the project by using transient plant transfection methods actually delayed our work. We later decided to go back to using the permanent Arabidopsis transfection method mediated by Agrobacterium tumefaciens to create Arabidopsis mutants that embed the siRNAs for testing, but we were not able to create enough mutants by the end of the project to initiate the tests.
